basic_info.description: ðŸ‘‹ I'm Elysia Lopez, and I'm a CS student at Northwestern University. I enjoy working on projects across the stack, from working on front-end frameworks (React, Django), to APIs (ASP.NET), to databases (SQL, MongoDB). I enjoy coding from both a creative and an analytical aspect, and I constantly challenge myself to learn new tools and algorithms. I look forward to every opportunity to create something bigger than myself.

projects.title: Battleships Game
projects.description: A full-stack project that involves a multiplayer Battleships game, hosted on a SQL database and utilizing a C# web API with a JS interface.

projects.title: 8-Puzzle Game + A* Solver
projects.description: Uses the C# Blazor framework; A 3x3 tile game where the player can slide tiles around to put them in order. Includes an Auto-Solve option, which uses an A* pathfinding algorithm to demonstrate the fastest way to win.

projects.title: Bit-Talk
projects.description: A hackathon project written in Python; A media-sharing platform for programming students to share work-based experiences with younger students. Built with Django & backed by a SQLite database.

projects.title: PoetryMood
projects.description: A web app that generates a poem using GPT-2, & classifies the mood of poem via Multinomial Naive Bayes classifier. Created UI using React. Built for the Northwestern IEEE Club yearly showcase.

projects.title: Pebble: Dating Site
projects.description: A web app intended for dating site purposes. Generates a random personality question every day that users can respond to, and then browse answers to. Built for a Valentine's-themed hackathon.

projects.title: Clowder
projects.description: An educationally social web app that shows a live, interactive map of Northwestern students' public invitations to study groups. Uses React for UI, Elixir for responsive backend, and Firebase for authentication. Built for Northwestern Wildhacks hackathon.

projects.title: Derivative Visualizer
projects.description: An educational tool that visualizes a derivative relating to the limit of the slopes. Built using the C# Windows Forms framework.
